message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy is consistent with a mitochondrial disorder, caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA. Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of both normal and mutated mitochondrial DNA in the same cell. This can lead to variability in symptom expression and severity, which would explain why the son is not affected even if he carries the same mutation as the daughter. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same disease, phenotypic heterogeneity refers to the same mutation causing different symptoms in different individuals, and genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy suggests a mitochondrial disorder, which can be caused by heteroplasmy. Heteroplasmy is the presence of both normal and mutated mitochondrial DNA in the same cell or organism, which can lead to variable expression of the disease. This can explain the fact that the mother's son does not seem to be affected. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations at the same locus causing the same phenotype, while phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different phenotypes caused by the same mutation. Genetic heterogeneity refers to the same phenotype caused by mutations at different loci.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of red ragged fibers on the muscle biopsy suggests a mitochondrial disorder. Heteroplasmy is the term used when cells within an individual have different mitochondrial DNA mutations. This can explain why only the daughter is affected while the son is not.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The muscle biopsy findings suggest mitochondrial myopathy, which can be caused by heteroplasmy - the presence of both normal and abnormal mitochondrial DNA within an individual. This can explain why only the daughter is affected, as she may have inherited a higher proportion of the abnormal mitochondrial DNA compared to her brother. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same disease, phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different symptoms caused by the same mutation, and genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same disease. None of these options fully explains the scenario presented in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy suggest a mitochondrial disorder. Heteroplasmy refers to the phenomenon where the presence of both normal and mutant mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in an individual's cells. It can explain why one child is affected and the other is not, as the levels of heteroplasmy can vary between different individuals. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same phenotype, phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different phenotypes caused by the same mutation, and genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy suggests mitochondrial disease, which can be caused by heteroplasmy. This refers to the presence of a mixture of normal and mutated mitochondrial DNA in the same individual or tissue. The son may not have inherited the same level of mutated mitochondrial DNA as the daughter, leading to differences in symptoms. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing a disease, phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different symptoms caused by the same mutation, and genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The muscle biopsy results suggest mitochondrial disease, which can be caused by heteroplasmy- a condition where different cells contain different ratios of mutant vs normal mitochondrial DNA. This can occur sporadically or be inherited from the mother. The son may have received a lower proportion of mutant mitochondrial DNA compared to the daughter. Option A (allelic heterogeneity) refers to different mutations occurring in the same gene, option B (phenotypic heterogeneity) refers to different phenotypes resulting from the same mutation, and option C (genetic heterogeneity) refers to different genes causing the same phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mitochondrial disorder causing the red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy is inherited through the mother's mitochondria. Heteroplasmy refers to the phenomenon where the proportion of normal and mutated mitochondria can vary in different tissues of the same individual or in different individuals from the same mother, which may explain why the son does not seem to be affected. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same phenotype, while phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing different phenotypes. Genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the information provided, the disorder is likely a mitochondrial disease, which can show heteroplasmy, where different cells within an individual have different amounts and proportions of mutant mitochondrial DNA. This can result in variability in symptoms or lack of symptoms among affected family members, as seen in the mother’s son who is not affected. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same disease, while genetic heterogeneity refers to different genes causing the same disease. Phenotypic heterogeneity refers to different symptoms among individuals with the same genetic disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of red ragged fibers in the muscle biopsy suggests mitochondrial disease, which can be caused by heteroplasmy. Heteroplasmy is the presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA in an individual, and the severity and onset of mitochondrial disease can vary depending on the percentage of mutated mtDNA. This can explain why the daughter is affected while the son is not. Allelic heterogeneity refers to different mutations in the same gene causing the same disease, while phenotypic heterogeneity refers to the same genetic mutation causing different clinical outcomes. Genetic heterogeneity occurs when different genes can cause the same clinical phenotype.
